dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you. Please feel free to share what's on your mind or what brings you here today.

Hey, thanks. I've been feeling pretty nervous about my work in the lab. I just can't shake the fear of messing something up, and it's kind of getting in the way of me experimenting and learning confidently.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a detailed account of their nervousness in the lab, including thoughts, feelings, and contextual anecdotes. Rapport appears to be building, with the client reflecting on their behavior and expressing a desire to change. The goals of the Exploring phase seem to be met, suggesting readiness to move to the Guiding phase to strengthen motivation for change.

dialogue_total.statement: It's understandable to feel that way when there's so much pressure. What would it look like for you to feel more confident and curious in your work?

I think it would mean feeling comfortable enough to explore and try things without that constant worry of making a mistake. Like, being able to approach problems more openly and learn from them, instead of just freezing up or immediately asking for help.

statement.reasoning: The client articulated a desire to move beyond anxiety to be more confident and inquisitive, indicating Change Talk. They expressed a specific change goal: becoming more comfortable in the lab. Confidence is somewhat indicated by their willingness to consider action (e.g., adjusting meds). While ambivalence is present, the session has effectively guided the client towards readiness to plan for change.

dialogue_total.statement: That sounds like a valuable goal, to feel more at ease while experimenting and learning. Based on what you've mentioned, one option could be setting small, manageable goals in your experiments to build confidence gradually. Another might be practicing self-compassion, allowing yourself room to make mistakes as part of the learning process. What steps do you think might help you start moving in that direction?

I like the idea of setting small goals—maybe starting with getting comfortable with one piece of equipment at a time. And I definitely need to be kinder to myself when I mess up; maybe reminding myself that making mistakes is part of getting better could help.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a clear goal to become more confident in the lab and has outlined a concrete action plan to start with small goals and practice self-compassion. Barriers related to fear of mistakes and anxiety have been discussed, with a potential strategy of medication adjustment. The client shows signs of commitment and readiness to take steps, indicating readiness to advance.

dialogue_total.statement:
Embracing those small steps and practicing self-compassion sounds like a thoughtful and practical plan. Focusing on becoming familiar with one piece of equipment at a time can really help you build your confidence incrementally. It’s great to hear that you're open to changing how you talk to yourself when mistakes happen, viewing them as opportunities to learn and grow is such an empowering approach. 

You’re setting yourself up for success with these strategies. Remember that progress takes time and it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Keep acknowledging your efforts and the progress you're making, no matter how small it seems. 

The next step could be to schedule some time each week to reflect on what you’ve learned and celebrate those wins. I'm here to support you along the way, so feel free to reach out if you need to talk or adjust your plan. You're doing great, and I'm confident in your ability to navigate this with resilience and grace.
Thanks for the support and ideas. I'll try setting aside some time each week to check in with myself and see how things are going. It might help ease some of the pressure I'm feeling.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated their concerns and developed a clear plan with coping strategies and steps forward. The conversation naturally concluded with mutual understanding of next steps, warranting the session to end.

concern:
title: Are you nervous or confident in lab?
Today my partner came to keep me company while I was working late in lab. I noticed how intrigued he was by everything in our lab (he is not in science or any science adjacent field). He was walking around touching all the instruments we had out, poking around (being mindful to not break or change anything) and was overall just very interested. 

It made me think: not even I go around poking around my lab because I'm worried I'll break something. Even when I come across an issue in lab (this is my first time doing labwork in years), I email my advisors for help instead of poking around old data to see if anything matches up because I don't want to accidentally delete something.

I guess it will take time to gain more confidence and I should probably up my anxiety meds but how are you usually in lab? Nervous or confidently inquisitive? I want to become like the latter but worried (ha) that I will never break out of my nervous shell.
